awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Early Career Geoscience Faculty Development Workshop
awd_abstract_narration:
Providing learning and support opportunities for early-career faculty is an important strategy to improve undergraduate geoscience education, strengthen faculty research and scholarship, and address issues of diversity and inclusion in the Geosciences. To this end, in partnership with the National Association of Geoscience Teachers, a team of experienced faculty leaders in geoscience education will host three annual workshops to help early-career geoscientists advance their understanding of best practices in pedagogy. The project supports NSF goals of fostering the development of a globally competitive scientific and engineering workforce.

The Early Career Faculty Workshops will be held at the University of Maryland and will include approximately seventy-five participants each summer. The workshops will be nationally advertised, and participation by faculty who are from minority serving institutions and community colleges will be encouraged. In addition to evaluation of the workshop activities, the project will complete a comprehensive evaluation of the impact of the Early Career Workshop program, including a longitudinal study of past participants. This evaluation will provide important insights into the long-term impact of early career professional development and training. This project is funded by Division of Undergraduate Education, the Division of Earth Sciences, Division of Ocean Sciences, and the Office of Polar Programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported the Early Career Geoscience Faculty: Teaching, Research, and Managing Your Career workshop from 2018-2020. The grant supported evaluation of each annual workshop and a retrospective study to assess the impact of the workshop on geoscience faculty.

The Early Career Geoscience Faculty: Teaching, Research, and Managing Your Career workshop is a multi-day workshop that aims to provide concrete skills to support early career (pre-tenure) faculty. Since its inception in 1999, the workshop has focused on the three-part nature of academic appointments by dedicating time to topics on teaching, research, and balancing work and life priorities. The three workshops supported by this grant were held:

July 22-26, 2018, at the University of Maryland, College Park, MD with optional visit to NSF on July 27;

July 28-August 1, 2019, at the University of Maryland, College Park, MD with an optional visit to NSF on August 2; and

July 27-July 30, 2020, held virtually because of the COVID-19 pandemic, with an optional virtual visit to NSF on August 4-5.

The workshop goals were for participants to:

  • Learn about setting course goals, strategies for active learning, and methods for assessing student learning.
  • Share ideas and strategies for teaching one or more courses.
  • Consider successful strategies for maintaining an active research program and advising, supervising, and mentoring undergraduate and/or graduate research students.
  • Discuss life as an early-career faculty member and explore ways to balance teaching, research, and service responsibilities.
  • Leave with examples of assignments and activities for various courses, strategies for balancing competing demands, a support network of other early career faculty, and a plan for managing your early career as an academic.

Evaluation consisted of feedback collected during and following each annual workshop and a retrospective study. The annual workshop evaluation was conducted via online surveys that included daily "roadchecks" to provide formative input and an end of workshop survey that collected summative feedback. Participants consistently reported high satisfaction with the workshop and described their learning about teaching methods and strategies, influences on their research program, and the value of the Early Career (EC) network. A multi-method retrospective survey was conducted using interviews and a survey.

The retrospective interview study was conducted in 2019, involving 27 past workshop participants purposefully selected across workshop years, appointment type, and social identity demographics. The interviews characterized how participants thought their EC workshop experience influenced their professional life. More than half of the interviewees reported the teaching aspect as the most important part of the workshop. Some faculty described it as important because it was their first exposure to evidence-based teaching strategies, while others valued the focused time to think deeply about teaching. Key to the workshop research aspects, more than a third of the interviewees stated that the visit to NSF gave them confidence and insight that had lasting influence on their research path. All interviewees reported on the lasting value of the EC network. In describing the value of this network, participants cited friendly faces at professional meetings and important and persistent connections (people, professional organizations, and fields of research).

The retrospective survey was administered online in the winter of 2020 and received 365 responses (38% response rate). The retrospective survey aimed to characterize what role (if any) the workshop had in respondents' professional careers, what worked well, what was useful, and areas for workshop improvement. Like the interviewees, survey respondents reported that the workshop provided important connections at the workshop and during their early career years following the workshop. Participants stated that their participation in the workshop gave them connections to a broader range of resources (70% reporting this as moderately to highly valuable), connected them with a broader network of people (56% indicating this as moderately to highly valuable), and provided them with colleagues who they could correspond with about research or teaching (62% stating this as moderately to highly valuable). Some statistically significant differences emerged by demographics. Two-year college faculty respondents tended to report higher value for the teaching and work / life balance aspects of the workshop. They also reported higher value for the workshop aspects that helped them in "realizing you are not alone" and "understanding multiple viewpoints." In contrast, those participants at doctoral universities reported higher value in the workshop aspects that helped them to connect with NSF program officers. Those respondents who self-identified as persons of color tended to rate the workshop's role in connecting them with NSF program officers and peer and leader connections that lasted following the workshop as of higher value. 

Across a set of seven potential additional topics to the workshop, there was overwhelming support for adding strategies to promote diversity, equity, and inclusion (84% of survey respondents reported this would have been moderately to highly valuable to their success as a faculty member) which was consistent with the interviewees' responses.
